fields.description:
An end-user was looking to manage/monitor multiple related projects in a portfolio within Bamboo. It is possible to [manage (ALL or one) project|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Managing+deployment+projects], however they are looking to manage a set of related projects. 
So for instance, portfolio A has projects AP1 and AP2 and AP3. They want to see the status of each, build time for each, etc. but on one dashboard within Bamboo.
fields.summary: Allow managing multiple projects

fields.description:
Easier way to update custom variables to be shared across Stages within a Build Plan.

Consider the following scenario:

1. <Build Plan A>.<Stage 1>.<Job 1> ---> Update custom variable value

2. <Build Plan A>.<Stage 2>.<Job 1> ---> Use custom variable value from Stage 1

Currently the only way to achieve this is making use of the "Bamboo Inject Variables Plugin" and have the custom variables added to an external file - in order to achieve this we need to add a 'Script' task to Stage 1 to generate the variables and the file. From there we can create an artifact definition that will be generated as a result from building Stage 1. Now we can go to Stage 2 and download the artifact produced from Stage 1 that will contain the variables. After that we can add an 'Inject Bamboo variables' task to read the artifact produced by Stage 1 and create a 'Script' task (or any other task) to use the variables from the artifact. Every time we want to update the values of the variables we can go to the Script task in Stage 1, change the values inside the Script task and generate a new artifact that will be downloaded by Stage 2 and so on.

It would be nice to have an easier way to accomplish this task without having to use a plugin/external file containing custom variables so we can regurarly update them, something like a built-in feature.
fields.summary: Ability to update custom variables to be shared across multiple Stages within a Build Plan

fields.description: On plan and global variables configuration pages, shell environment variables are said to be "$BAMBOO_MY_VARIABLE_NAME". fields.description:
We used the custom variables feature heavily in our build process, such as, building with specific branches, build revisions, and some other configs.

Many times, we simply want to rebuild using the custom variables config from an existing build, but we cannot do that easily as we have to repeatedly go to Run > Run Customized > Re-enter the same custom variables. As such, I'd like to suggest a feature that Bamboo team can easily implement which will make our life much easier. In the "Run with Customized" dialog, please introduce an option that allows users to pre-fill the custom variables from the last build (or from a specific build if possible, with last build selected by default). See the screenshot for the proposed user interface and description.

Note that this feature is not same with "Re-run this build" currently available in Bamboo. Re-run this build will use the same commit, while we actually want to perform another new build, but with all custom variables filled automatically.
fields.summary: Remember custom variables when running a build plan

fields.description:
We have a deployment project which, in one task, downloads a large artifact from a source plan. One time, when running this task, the artifact download was taking an unusually long time. Upon inspecting the agent logs, it was timing out and retrying.

I clicked the 'Stop Deployment' button twice (about one minute apart) but the deployment did not stop. Eventually the task was able to download the file and it moved on to subsequent tasks and finished the deployment.

I would have expected that, when I clicked 'Stop Deployment', the deployment:
- should have stopped immediately -- no waiting for a download to time out; and
- the deployment definitely should not have moved on to other tasks after the download completed.

Output from the deployment logs show:
{noformat}
simple	06-Mar-2015 05:30:01	Starting task 'Download release contents' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	06-Mar-2015 05:30:01	Preparing to download plan result BAMBOOUPGRADE-DOWNLOAD-25 artifact: Shared artifact: [StandaloneTarball], pattern: [*.tar.gz] anchored at: [./]
command	06-Mar-2015 05:35:22	Request to stop '271515650-277512218-312737795' received from mknight
command	06-Mar-2015 05:36:32	Request to stop '271515650-277512218-312737795' received from mknight
simple	06-Mar-2015 05:39:38	Artifact [StandaloneTarball] downloaded successfully in 576s to: /./
simple	06-Mar-2015 05:39:38	Finished task 'Download release contents' with result: Success
simple	06-Mar-2015 05:39:38	Starting task 'Upload Bamboo archive to BAC' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scripttask:task.builder.script'
...
{noformat}

fields.description:
h5. Problem
The {{KahaDB}} directory under {{home/jms-store/bamboo}} will store caches/logs for agent-server communication. This directory is only purged upon restart, so if an instance runs without being restarted for an extended period of time, the size of the directory will just keep growing.

h5. Suggestion
Either create a documentation on all the suggested housekeeping tasks or files/directories to monitor, or more conveniently implement a feature in Bamboo to perform such housekeeping tasks itself.
fields.summary: Bamboo housekeeping

This is incorrect, as the build is paused.

fields.description:
*Steps to Replicate*
# Create a linked repository with a URL to be fillied by some plan/global variable
# Now create a plan with checkout task
# Create a plan variable that contains some variables that can complete the URL
# Now run the plan build

*Expected behavior*
The variable should be substituted just once

*Current behaviour*
The variable gets substituted a couple of times.
{code}
simple	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Starting task 'Checkout Default Repository' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout'
simple	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Running preRetrieveSourceCode task...
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
simple	03-Mar-2015 21:08:42	Updating source code to revision: 2
{code}
Down the lane again, the pre-build plugins like the  Clover Grails PreBuild Action and the VCS Version Collector also substitute the variable in a looping manner
{code}
simple	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Running pre-build action: Clover Grails PreBuild Action
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
simple	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Running pre-build action: VCS Version Collector
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
command	03-Mar-2015 21:08:44	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.path} with X
{code}

The overall effect is that if we have some subsequent jobs, the substitution creates duplicate entries in the variable_substitution table.. The biggest issue is that if this looping is done a couple of times, the overall build will be sluggish which in turn will keep the agents busy leaving some builds hanging in the queue.
fields.summary: Variable substitution on repository URL loops

fields.description:
Standard support of latest version of Oracle database 11g (11.2.0.4) ends in January 2016. After that time a premium subscription will be required to obtain support from Oracle. 

Therefore we require support for Oracle 12c database in Bamboo ideally by early December 2015.
* Are there any known issues running Bamboo with an Oracle 12c backend database?
* Are there any database features being used by Bamboo which are deprecated in 12c?
fields.summary: Support for Oracle 12c database in Bamboo

fields.description:
When using PHPUnit 4.3.4 with Bamboo 5.7.2, my PHPUnit task for "Log test execution to an XML file" fails due to "unrecognized option --log-xml"

I even tried phpunit --log -xml from the command line and same error occurs.

For starters, is PHPUnit 4.3.4 supported? If so, how can I send results to a XML file for reporting? In the past, I have done this for generating a JUnit XML report via PHPUnit - is that possible?
fields.summary: PHPUnit 4.3.4 test task not working due to --log-xml not recgonized

fields.description:
Not entirely sure about this button, but shutting down and terminating something is definitely not the same thing, just like with BAM-15615:

Caption: "Request agent stop"
Hint: "Agent will attempt to terminate after the any currently build has finished" (btw this seems to be grammatically incorrect)

fields.description:
Enable support for Bamboo to scan Bamboo Home/lib for the mysql connector.

In some cases, this is more convenient as the extra step to place the connector in the installation directory can be removed during the upgrade process.
fields.summary: Support placing MYSQL connector in Home directory

fields.description:
When I request to run a build, in all cases on my system, the task "rerun failed/incomplete jobs" is an irrelevant option, and is more confusing than its worth. Consider that in the scenario I have only 1 job, and it failed, there is no difference between running "failed/incomplete" and running the whole plan.

My suggestion is that not be an option, if the plan only has one stage and one job. The purpose for this request is that the interface is less verbose and confusing, especially for new customers who are trying Bamboo out. They most commonly don't have more than one job, and they want a simple interface.
fields.summary: "Rerun failed/incomplete jobs" often irrelevant (if only 1 job)

fields.description:
Two days ago on our Bamboo project I switched the repository on one of my Continuously Integrating build plans. This resulted in all of our branch plans on that build plan to be simultaneously queued for rebuilding. This caused a big problem, as the builds weren't exactly quickly executed. Ideally any existing branch plans won't be detected as modified when a Repo is replaced with another reference to the same repo (one was a linked repo, and the second was a Stash repo with shallow cloning enabled).

I realize this may be working as expected, but I certainly didn't expect all the branch plans to be queued simply by switching the Repository on the build plan.
fields.summary: Change Repo Causes Rebuilds

fields.description:
Hey Guys,
Please correct me if this is intended, I'm running into the following issue:

1. I have a CI build plan setup with some plan branches (dev, acceptance, staging, production)
2. I have a linked repository setup to the "dev" branch by default
3. In my CI build plan branch "acceptance" I'm triggering the build on changes on the "dev" branch.
4. I have my auto merge branch setup to checkout "acceptance" and merge from "dev" and push "acceptance" on success.

When the build runs after picking up changes from the "dev" branch, my auto merge settings show checked out "dev" and merge from "dev" and push "Not Required" even though my setup specifies to checkout the "acceptance" branch and merge "dev" and on success push "acceptance".

Now, what seems to actually do what I want, is to override the repository settings on that branch and set my branch to acceptance there as well. When I run the branch manually, it checks out "acceptance", merges "dev" and pushes "acceptance" as I intend. Problem is, I can no longer trigger this build on changes to the "dev" branch as my override is listening on the acceptance branch.

Am I going about this completely wrong?
fields.summary: Repository Auto Branch Merge
Disable Job prevents build from running successfully when Artifacts are shared

fields.description:
For unknown reason, the build is left in a zombie state and doesn't finish:

!zombie.png!

h6. Impact
* The build doesn't finish and keeps running
* The build result doesn't show up on the build result overview page (obviously, it is not finished, yet)
* It does not get killed; is stays there (forever)
* Looking at the build result page results an endless refresh loop

h6. Workaround
* Manually update the limit of concurrently running builds to 2
* *Restart the server*

h6. More information

fields.description:
The settings editor page for "Elastic Bamboo configuration" has a checkbox with the following title and label:
{quote}Automatic shutdown
Automatically terminate elastic instance when elastic agent process ends{quote}

This is tragically misleading, since instance termination means that it's deleted, whereas shutting down just shuts down the VM for reducing costs.
fields.summary: Elastic configuration: Shutdown != Terminate

fields.description:
h4. Improvement:

Would like to configure Bamboo to use an Active Directory group for authorization. That will allow our customers to manage user access to a project within Bamboo from Active Directory.
fields.summary: Add the ability to use Active Directory for group management

fields.description:
We have certain tasks in the build which should be skipped if the build is being re-run. I noticed that bamboo already writing a property to METADATA for this e.g: When I rerun a build and its successful i see the following key value pair on METADATA Tab: 
RerunBuildTriggerReason.noOfRetries	1 (See Capture.png)

I tried using it as a property, see metadata.png but if I echo ${retries}, it doesn't have the value and instead has ${bamboo.RerunBuildTriggerReason.noOfRetries}. 

Can we expose the METADATA properties so those can be used during the builds.
fields.summary: Using Bamboo build Metadata as property

fields.description:
*Problem*
Artifact names with unicode character can be downloaded but when opened users receive 404 error. Even when {{conf/server.xml}} *URIEncoding* value is set to "UTF-8" inconsistent results are displayed. 

In the logs when attempting to access {{あ.txt}}:
{noformat}
File does not exist/can't be read: /<bamboo-home>/artifacts/TPR-TPL/shared/build-00006/arifacts/???.txt
{noformat}

h4. Duplication Steps:
# Create an artifact where the file name:
## Includes multibyte characters (e.g. あ and い).
## Artifacts exist over 2.
# Download artifact
# Select artifact that has been downloaded
(i) Depending on status of URIEncoding in {{server.xml}} the title will display as "?"
# "Page not found" error

h4. Browser success/failure breakdown:
||browser||'URIEncoding="UTF-8"' to 'connector' of conf/server.xml.|| not exist || exist||
|chrome|Filename|OK|OK|
|chrome|FileContents|broken link|garbled|
|chrome|FileDowndoad|OK|only *txt*|
|IE11|Filename|garbled|garbled|
|IE11|FileContents|broken link|OK|
|IE11|FileDowndoad|*.* change to *_*|only *.txt*|
|FireFox|Filename|OK|OK|
|FireFox|FileContents|broken link|OK|
|FireFox|FileDowndoad|OK|only *.txt*|

h4. Workaround
Compress artifacts without UTF-8 character
fields.summary: "Page not found" error after download of artifcats with multibyte character

fields.description:
h4. Problem:
Windows images should hide the startup script configuration until BAM-15588 in addressed. This is causing confusion as per our documentation, [Creating a custom elastic image|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Creating+a+custom+elastic+image], only UNIX/Linux have the ability to utilize the startup script.
fields.summary: Windows images should hide startup script configuartion

fields.description:
h4. Problem:
Per [Creating a custom elastic image|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Creating+a+custom+elastic+image] startup script support is limited to UNIX/Linux. However, the option to configure is displayed. 

h4. Improvement:
Add startup script support to Windows images.

fields.description:
Bamboo SSH proxy server, which is launched both on Bamboo machine and on build agent machines, always binds to a random port. The port is reset on Bamboo restart.

It would be nice to have the ability to control that port - either to provide a specific port to bind or to provide a range of ports (or any form of restriction/control). A possible solution might involve using a system property.
fields.summary: Allow to control Bamboo SSH proxy server port

fields.description:
The current wallboard view gets to a stage where there are more plans than will fit on a single screen without scrolling the browser view.  This is because the size of the individual plan "cards" do not scale with the window size (in Google Chrome/Firefox at least).

This is unfortunate when the view is on a large screen in the office, as some failing builds can be hidden by a large number of green builds.   Other than a "feel-good" factor, displaying green builds is not helpful, as these builds requrie no action!

Possible solutions:

1.  The ability to filter out green builds entirely and show only red and in progress builds.
2.  Three sections to the wallboard - green, red, in progress, whose size can be adjusted and whose plan cards automatically scale in size to fit that section.

Or, really, anything that fulfills the criteria that the wallboard only contains information of interest.
fields.summary: Wallboard contains too much irrelevant information

fields.description: The Plan summary page, viewed by someone _without_ "Create Plan" permission should show the arrangement of Stages, Jobs and tasks.  This view should be read-only, and there is a discussion to be had (I guess) as to whether task content should be visible.  Perhaps that could be optional.
fields.summary: View Plan structure without Create Plan permission

fields.description:
Plans can be configured to trigger further downstream plans, but nowhere can you get:

1) a visual representation of the parent/child relationships for a plan.

2) any post-build information in a parent plan as to which child plans it triggered

#1 above could be solved by an icon similar to the branch and deployment icons you see in any view where plans are listed.  This could take to a page showing  the parent/child relationship diagrammatically.

#2 The build summary page should have a section "Child Plans Triggere", listing the child plans, and their statuses (ok, failed, in progress).
fields.summary: Better view of parent/child build plans.

fields.description:
h4. Problem:
When an agent is stuck in the *Pending* state none of the instances shutdown parameters in Elastic Instance Management are respected as the agent has not yet reached the *Idle* state.

h4. Improvement:
Add the ability for Bamboo to detect when agents are hung and add a parameter that can be customized to say "if agent state = pending for >/= variable set by user, notify user". 

This will help with intermittent agent startup issues charging customers when the instance couldn't be fully utilized.
fields.summary: Add parameter to notify admin or shut down agents that are hung in Pending state for too long

fields.description:
On Linux, when artifacts are created and then deployed, all file permissions are lost. So when executable binaries are deployed, their executable bit is not set.

In order to work around this I either need to write a script job that will re-set the correct permissions or tar everything up before creating the artifacts and then pass around a tarball rather than just pure artifacts.

This seems like a major oversight. Could you advise on how to properly do this if possible, or add this to Bamboo in the future if not?

Thank you.
fields.summary: Preserve file permissions in artifacts

fields.description:
Is it a possibility to implement checking which commits will be added while starting new plan before starting such plan?
Such feature will be usefull in case 'on demand starting plans' when someone is waiting for some commits and there is no need to start whole plan when some commits arent available in repositories yet.
Of course such checking should list only commits added from previous build until current moment.
fields.summary: Commit prediction before starting a plan

fields.description:
Hi,

I would like to evaluate the exit code of a build job in a final task for further actions.

Would be helpful if bamboo itself would store the last exit code into a global variable, like ${bamboo.lastExitCode}.

Regards
Marco

fields.description:
Symptoms:

Instances hosted on our SC1 infrastructure (run 'host example.atlassian.net' or 'nslookup example.atlassian.net' and look for ash1 or sc1 to identify) experience slowness during the publish artifacts phase of a Bamboo build. For example, uploading 50MB of artifacts takes around 400 seconds versus 15 seconds on other data centres.

*Steps to replicate:*

# Create a build plan with https://bitbucket.org/matthewhunter/bigfile as the repo
# Add * to the artifact definitions
# Run a build

*Result:*

Bamboo takes ~400 seconds to publish all artifacts

*Expected Result:*

Bamboo takes ~15 seconds to publish all artifacts.

*Workaround:*

# [Copy your Bamboo AMI|http://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2013/03/12/announcing-ami-copy-for-amazon-ec2/ ] to the US West region
# [Configure elastic bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Cloud/Configuring+Elastic+Bamboo] to use the region US West.

*Update*

We've also found it to be slow when connecting from ASH1 to Asia Pacific.
fields.summary: Publishing artifacts in Bamboo Cloud is extremely slow

Inappropriate details populated in ssh connection assistance text for Bamboo elastic cloud instances.

In this case, with the key in ~/Downloads and an Ubuntu image, pasting this text in a console results in a heap of failure. A template with 'replace this value' fields would be more helpful than an incorrectly populated example.

Below is a copy of the log. Example workflow: A container is created, the bamboo-agent.cfg.xml is copied, the container runs the remote agent jar, and eventually the computer restarts. Once it finishes rebooting the whole process starts over again. The output of the log and the bamboo-agent.cfg.xml are listed below. Once the agent has registered the bamboo-agent.cfg.xml fields are overwritten with a new uuid, id, and name


Feb 16, 2015 6:50:22 PM A remote agent is loading on minion-10-cyberpower-tt-10.6.24.10-container-a (10.6.24.10).
Feb 16, 2015 6:50:36 PM Remote agent "minion-10-cyberpower-tt-10.6.24.10-container-a-test" has registered.
Feb 16, 2015 6:51:37 PM A remote agent is loading on minion-10-cyberpower-tt-10.6.24.10-container-a (10.6.24.10).
Feb 16, 2015 6:51:50 PM Remote agent "minion-10-cyberpower-tt-10.6.24.10-container-a-test (2)" has registered.
Feb 16, 2015 7:01:10 PM Remote agent 'minion-10-cyberpower-tt-10.6.24.10-container-a-test' was unresponsive and has gone offline.

bamboo-agent.cfg.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
  <configuration>
     <buildWorkingDirectory>/root/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir</buildWorkingDirectory>
     <agentUuid>a3b0ff27-1a2c-4609-8f01-5cc49705efe7</agentUuid>

Thanks!

Some of my build plans do have those long Location and Copy Pattern values in the Artifacts

This is for On Demand

fields.description:
I have a build plan that automatically builds master (via the repository configuration) and a whole bunch of branches matched by regex (via the branches configuration).

The master branch is not explicitly called out in the branches configuration.

When looking at the branch details tab of the plan (where you can see the results for the most recent build of any branch) I expect to see master. I only see the matched branches.

The reason this is desirable is because to get a view of everything that has built you need to look at both the "plan summary" tab and "branches" tab.

In more detail, this plan loads software onto embedded hardware, and it is often useful to know what software is on the hardware. That means it is useful to know what branch built last.

In addition; semantically "master" is a branch and so it's confusing.

fields.description:
Automatic/manual Clover integration mail fail.

*Problem:*
Parsing Clover's XML report file consumes ~7 * file size of the heap memory. In case of large projects and thus also large XML report files, it may cause that a build agent will fail with an "out of memory" or a "GC overhead limit exceeded" error. 

*Workaround:*

Don't generate large XML Clover coverage reports. Prepare a custom configuration for an XML report to make it smaller.

In case of Ant:
 * if you're using automatic Clover integration, then the reporting target is named "clover.report" (see clover.jar/clover.xml file); define such target in your build.xml file to override default settings
 * if you're using manual Clover integration, then find your target responsible for report generation
 * disable generation of source line information for XML report in order to reduce file size

Example:

{code:xml}
<target name="clover.report">
        <clover-report>
            <current outfile="target/site/clover">
                <format type="html"/>
            </current>
            <current outfile="target/site/clover/clover.xml">
                <format type="xml" srcLevel="false"/> <!-- USE srcLevel=false" -->
            </current>
        </clover-report>
    </target>
{code}

In case of Maven:
 * use the reportDescriptor to customize the report - see https://docs.atlassian.com/maven-clover2-plugin/latest/clover-mojo.html#reportDescriptor
fields.summary: Clover Results Collector causes OOM on agents for large Clover XML report files

fields.description:
This is a transcription of BSP-17418 (https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/10/BSP-17418), made at the request of Atlassian Support (Rafael P. Sperafico.)
~~~~~
    On the Build Dashboard page, at the bottom of the Projects list, is a button labeled "Show More Plans."
    The default project list size seems to be 6 projects. If you have more projects and want to see them, you click this button, and more projects are displayed..
    So far, so good.
    Say you've clicked this "Show More Plans" button, and then selected a project or plan link to go to another page.
    Now say you clicked on the wrong link or found the info you sought, and now want to go back to the dashboard page. You do this either by opening a new browser tab/window and re-entering the dashboard URL, or by going back to the previous page in your existing browser tab/window.
    Let's say you're too lazy to open a new window or tab and come up with the correct URL, so you go back to the previous page in your existing browser tab/window.
    This action gets you to the dashboard, however, only six projects are displayed. Worse, the "Show More Plans" button is now grayed out, so there is no immediate way to display the hidden plans!!!

    The workaround is to "force-reload" the dashboard page to restore the viability of the button, then click the button to see plans after #6.  A simple reload does not resolve the issue.  A cache-refresh reload ("Force Reload") is necessary.

    This issue has been present since I started using bamboo in June '15. It remains in the current versaion we're using:
    Atlassian Bamboo version 5.7.2 build 5716 - 02 Dec 14
fields.summary: Dashboard "Show More Plans" button requires page reload to work a 2nd time

fields.description: We typically have multiple parties who need to approve a release (PM, customer, DBA, etc.). So knowing that one random person approved the release isn't really useful to us. However, much more useful would be if multiple people could approve it. Even if there aren't workflow conditionals requiring certain number of or specific people that it must be approved by, at least let the person who is doing the deployment see that the right people have approved the release for deployment
fields.summary: Allow multiple approvers for a release

fields.description:
Deployment projects/environments can only deploy successful builds.

This is reasonable for many use cases but not all.

We are a mid-sized engineering team that wants to be able to deploy regularly and sometimes on-demand for release testing.

If a minor test fails that doesn't affect overall functionality, we cannot use our deployment environments to deploy the latest build, which blocks testing of important functionality. This requires us to quarantine tests and re-run builds that were already satisfactory for our needs - definitely a pain. We could also deploy out-of-ecosystem with our devops tools, but that's more time intensive, we love Bamboo, and I know this isn't a hard feature to implement : p.

I can only imagine this gets worse with more tests. If 30,000 tests pass and one fails, most teams would probably be very interested in determining behavior of deployment.

As a start, latest in addition to latest successful would be great. For more fine grained control, automatically accepting builds with less than N failures, or having the ability to manually specify latest successful vs. latest, or even a specific build number at deploy time would be valuable from our perspective.
fields.summary: As a developer, I want to deploy failed builds from Bamboo for testing
With deploy "Source Code Checkout" tasks, how can you specify a branch?

fields.description:
Let me set the scenario. I have an svn repository. In fact, I have many. They are interlinked via svn:externals. They have tight dependencies between them, and we often commit to both of them at the same time.

At 1:58pm, we had a commit go through on a repository. We'll call it apple-r155, made to the file:
     svn://svn/apple/trunk/main.cpp

At 2:00pm, Bamboo polled the repository and scheduled a build (#6). The agent was busy so the job was queued.

At svn://svn/apple/trunk, svn:externals is defined to be:
    svn://svn/banana/trunk banana
   (we actually use this notation, which means the same...)
     ^/../banana/trunk banana

And at 2:10pm, another commit happened to banana, banana-r97, but to:
     svn://svn/banana/trunk/foo.cpp

And another at 2:15pm, commit banana-r98, to:
     svn://svn/banana/trunk/bar.cpp
        (this isn't a necessary step to reproduce the problem, but it actually happened in our scenario at the time)

Finally, at 2:20pm, the agent became free to run, but it didn't notice at this time other changes to the repository. The log said that it was updating to revision apple-r155. It updated based on the revision number. But "svn up -r155" doesn't pass any meaning of banana's revision. The update step actually also pulled banana-r98, not banana-r96, but it didn't report to the build the changes that came with banana-r97 or banana-r98.

Once this job was done, it polled the repo again and found it should run another build (#7), to take in banana-r97 and banana-r98. This build did report the changes of banana-r97-98, but the actual build didn't reflect those changes. Instead, build #6 was actually reflecting those changes. 

The fix here, is that bamboo should do one of two things, contrary to what it currently does.

1) Every build should run "svn up --ignore-externals -r {2015-02-12 14:00:00} . banana"
   ... where the "2015-02-12 14:00:00" represents the time the svn repositories were checked. "banana" represents all externals.

  What this would do would be to ensure that only the changes polled for are the ones run during the build. This is only important for a job that is queued, where other commits might happen during the queuing of the job. If other changes happen while the job is in queue, then latter poll will account for those.

2) If build is queued for a time, the svn-poll should re-check for changes at the time of the actual update, and report all changes during the queuing to be part of the build that happened, such that the final result of build #6 (in the above scenario) would show 3 changes. Using this means, build #7 would not have happened.

  This is effectively calling the queuing time effectively the same as the quiet period, I think. That approach is fine with me.
fields.summary: Changes in svn:externals handled incorrectly, if committed while job is in queue

fields.description:
Currently in our brand we have a wide user base who use their own agents. The Bamboo environment is managed by a set of admins, and whenever the developers or automation engineers needs to administer an agent (e.g.: agent capabilities etc) unless permission is given, that engineer cannot do the needful in the interface. 

There is a file that can be put in the remote agent bin folder called bamboo-capablities.properties .... however we have found that this only allows the engineer to bootstrap the agent to Bamboo. Once a KVP is put there and loaded in the interface, if that KVP is removed from the file and the agent is restarted, that KVP persists in the interface. 

Please allow for administration to have granular permissions on agent configurations. Thanks
fields.summary: Allow certain administration to certain agents to certain users.

fields.description:
in our development we have a number of submodules. Our 'home grown' build system implemented an entire module of git commands, one of which the option to use the 'head' of submodules, rather than the checked in SHA1.

In migrating our build system to bamboo we no longer need to do anything with git and I would prefer to keep it that way by having bamboo support the git feature of submodule update --remote.

in the meantime, I will investigate the suggested workaround to simply add a task to run 'git submodule update --remote immediately following the source checkout task.
fields.summary: support git submodule update --remote feature of git in a bamboo build plan

fields.description: Jobs on remote agents may get into an invalid state if the logfile on the agent cannot be written (disk quota exceeded, directory not found, etc). In this case, the build cannot be stopped as the event cannot be logged on the agent, so the build will remain in "Stopping" state, even if the remote agent is restarted. The only workaround is to restart Bamboo server, which can be pretty inconvenient.
fields.summary: Build remains in Stopping status if agent fails to write logfile

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce
# Add _msdeploy.exe_ as an executable
# Add command task that use {{msdeploy}} and use {{-setParam:name="Foo Bar name",value=FooBarValue}} as argument in the command task
# Run plan

h4. Observation
The following error is thrown
{code}Error: Unrecognized argument '"-setParam:name="Foo'. All arguments must begin with "-".{code}

h4. Workarounds
Either:
a) Use parameters without any space to avoid the use of quotes as it's not interpreted correctly.
b) Use a script task instead of the command task
c) Create a script file that encapsulates the targeted command and arguments.
fields.summary: Quote character in Command task argument is not interpreted correctly

fields.description:
we have 20+ Sybase instances.  A "deploy" that involves a lot of schema changes and data conversion can take a long time.  Once a single Sybase instance has had a release deployed to it, the quickest way to get other Sybase instances up to the same release is to take a backup of the one deployed to and restore that to others.

But then Bamboo and Jira are unaware that this has occurred and will keep reporting the the other instance has some older release.

Is there a way of "applying" a release to an environment without actually deploying anything?
fields.summary: Is it possible to inform bamboo that an environment has been manually brought up to a release?

fields.description:
We'd like to add a deploy to Artifactory job that only runs when a bamboo variable has a certain value.  Is this possible?

If not, is there a way that we can populate to "snapshot" when a bamboo variable has a certain value and the "release" repository otherwise?
fields.summary: Is it possible to add a "conditional" job?

fields.description:
h2. Issue 1
h4. Problem:
Rerun build results in the following error in the UI:
{noformat}
An unexpected error has occurred
duplicate key: foo.bar (it is a global variable)
{noformat}

In the *atlassian-bamboo.log*:
{noformat}
2015-02-05 10:55:28,433 ERROR [http-apr-8085-exec-11] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] duplicate key: foo.bar
{noformat}

h2. Issue 2
h3. Summary
*Rerun falied/imcomplete jobs only* result on *Multiple entries with same key error*

h3. Environment
* Bamboo v5.10.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Project (_e.g..: Project_), Plan (_e.g.: Duplicate Variable_)
# Create 3 JOBs configured under the *Default Stage*
#* *Default Job*
#* *Second Job*
#* *Testing Job*
# Configure each JOB as follows:
||Default Job||
||Task||Configuration||
|*Inject Bamboo Variables*|Path to properties file{color:red}*{color}:
  *duplicate.variables.txt*
Namespace{color:red}*{color}:
  *inject*
Scope of the variables:
  \[x\] *Result*
|
|*Script*|{code}
echo "${bamboo.buildResultKey}"
echo "${bamboo.inject.INJECTED}"
{code}|
||Second Job||
||Task||Configuration||
|*Inject Bamboo Variables*|Path to properties file{color:red}*{color}:
  *duplicate.variables.txt*
Namespace{color:red}*{color}:
  *inject*
Scope of the variables:
  \[x\] *Result*
|
|*Script*|{code}
echo "${bamboo.buildResultKey}"
echo "${bamboo.inject.INJECTED}"
{code}|
||Testing Job||
||Task||Configuration||
|*Script*|{code}
exit 1
{code}|
(i) *exit 1* forces the job to fail which results in the *Rerun failed/incomplete jobs only* option to be revealed.
# Run the build (and expect it to fail).
# Rerun the build by hitting the option *Rerun falied/incomplete jobs only*

{panel:bgColor=#e3f7fc}
(i)   The following must be located in the Build Working Directory so it can be accessed by *Inject Bamboo Variables* task
{code:title=duplicate.variables.txt}

{code}
{panel}

h3. Expected Results

h3. Actual Results

*An unexpected error has occurred*
||(!)|Multiple entries with same key: inject.INJECTED=VariableDefinitionContextImpl{variableType=RESULT, key=inject.INJECTED, value=foo} and inject.INJECTED=VariableDefinitionContextImpl{variableType=RESULT, key=inject.INJECTED, value=foo}
Plan 'PROJ-DV' did not start|

The exception below is thrown and logged in the {{<bamboo-install>/logs/catalina.log}} file:

2016-07-12 12:05:28,720 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Multiple entries with same key: inject.INJECTED=VariableDefinitionContextImpl{variableType=RESULT, key=inject.INJECTED, value=foo} and inject.INJECTED=VariableDefinitionContextImpl{variableType=RESULT, key=inject.INJECTED, value=foo}
{code}

h3.Workaround
No workaroud available

 The above jira ticket fixed the issues we had with release version scheme for deployment project. This is working fine on trunk or master.

fields.description:
Stash v3.6.0
Bamboo v5.7.2

h5. Replicate issue (_Only trigger "{{Plan C}}" if "{{Plan A}}" and "{{Plan B}}" builds are successful_)

# create a repository in Stash
#* add the following content to the repository
{noformat}
./planA
./planB
{noformat}
# create a Project in Bamboo
#* create a Plan (Plan A)
#** set up Stash repository under "{{Plan configuration >> Repositories}}" tab
#** under "{{Advanced options}}", please select "{{Include only changes that matches}}" under "{{Include / Exclude files}}"
#** add the following to "{{File pattern}}"
{noformat}
^planA/.*
{noformat}
#** under "{{Plan configuration >> Triggers}}" tab, please select "{{Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed}}" as "{{Trigger type}}"
#** under "{{Plan configuration >> Dependencies}}" tab, please add "{{Plan C}}" under "{{Child plans}}"
#** add "{{Source Code Checkout}}" task
#* run build
#* create a Plan (Plan B)
#** set up Stash repository under "{{Plan configuration >> Repositories}}" tab
#** under "{{Advanced options}}", please select "{{Include only changes that matches}}" under "{{Include / Exclude files}}"
#** add the following to "{{File pattern}}"
{noformat}
^planB/.*
{noformat}
#** under "{{Plan configuration >> Triggers}}" tab, please select "{{Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed}}" as "{{Trigger type}}"
#** under "{{Plan configuration >> Dependencies}}" tab, please add "{{Plan C}}" under "{{Child plans}}"
#** add "{{Source Code Checkout}}" task
#* run build
#* create a Plan (Plan C)
#** add Script task
{noformat}
echo "hello world!"
{noformat}
#* run build

At this stage, you should have successful builds in "{{Plan A}}", "{{Plan B}}" and "{{Plan C}}".

Lets force a build failure by:
# going to "{{Plan A >> Plan configuration}}" and add an "{{Ant}}" task
# please, run build

At this stage, you should have successful builds in "{{Plan B}}" and "{{Plan C}}" but not "{{Plan A}}"

Lets commit something to "{{./planB}}" directory as this will trigger "{{Plan B}}".
Based on the configurartion above, "{{Plan C}}" will be triggered eventhough "{{Plan A}}" has a failure build.
